moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nge7: I don't know what this variation of the Ruy Lopez is called - it looks very passive and would require very careful play by Black to equalize - more standard is, of course, 3...a6
moves.4. O-O a6 5. Ba4 b5: A wasted tempo - the bishop has no real teeth on that diagonal, and Black is simply pushing pawns around instead of developing.
moves.6. Bb3 h6: Trying to stop the Knight from attacking f7 - the previous wasted moves have forced Black to waste yet another one
moves.7. c3 Bb7: Better was d6 and attempting to exchange the Bishop on b3
moves.8. d4 exd4: Very dubious. Cedes control of the center
moves.9. cxd4 Nb4: A rotten move. It attacks the e4 pawn, but nothing else, and the passivity of Black's K-side is about to make itself felt dramatically.
moves.10. Ne5 d5 11. Qf3 f6: Forced. We can see how simple lack of development turned from a passive game to a disaster.
moves.12. Qh5+ g6 13. Nxg6 Nxg6 14. Qxg6+ Kd7: Forcing the king to remain in the center
moves.15... Ke8 16. a3: Kicking the knight away from the defense of d5
moves.16... Nd3: Since c6 was a hopeless square (exd5 would have made the knight keep running) this is probably best, however, Black is still down a pawn, losing another, and facing a strong attack.
moves.18... a5: ? A big mistake. Black is already facing a miserable prospect, but this move just loses.
moves.21. Qg6+ Rf7 22. d6 Qxd6 23. Qxf7+ Kd7 2: The cavalry belatedly arrives, making White's attack irresistible. The threat is N(x)b5 and the arrival of the Q Rook
moves.25. Rxe7+ Kc6 26. Rxc7+ Kb6 27. Rxb7+ Kc: This move loses immediately, but after 20...Ka6 21. Nxb5 would decide things quickly
